Example

Evaluate the definite integral:

\({\displaystyle\int \dfrac{x^2}{x^3 +1 }\ \mathrm{d}x}\)

Solution

In this Example the derivative of the denominator is \(3x^2\) whereas the numerator is just \(x^2\). We adjust the numerator as follows:

\({\displaystyle\int \dfrac{x^2}{x^3 +1 }\ \mathrm{d}x} = {\displaystyle\dfrac{1}{3}\int \dfrac{3x^2}{x^3 +1 }\ \mathrm{d}x}\)

and integrate by the rule to get

\(\dfrac{1}{3}\ln|x^3 + 1| + c\)

Note that the sort of procedure in the last Example is only possible because we can move constant factors through the integral sign. It would be wrong to try to move terms involving the variable \(x\) in a similar way.
